ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Thinking about sports in a different way than I previously did
I was able to better my ability to interpret and understand the deeper meaning behind a lot of the text we read.
I became a better writer and I was able to analyze texts in a different way. I improved my abstract thinking.
Learned how to become a much better writer. Also leaned how to analyze sports writing and how sports writers think.
Sports and media, a lot of stuff about media and ideas about the connection of sports and community and stuff like that.
Sportswriting insight through history in reference to descriptions and accounts of famous athletes and sportsmen
How to analyze sports literature
I learned to think of a topic in a whole new manner, and tried to connect works and their characteristics as it relates to the course as a whole.
This course definitely helped teach me to look deeper into readings and analyze deeper.
A good course to develop group discussion skills and the ability to analyze texts about sports.

I learned to read, analyze, and think about different mediums of good sports literature. I've learned how each is powerful in their own way, and the different focuses of each. I now see sports in a different way and I feel like I can carry out a conversation about multiple sports (which is a plus in terms of social life).

While improving my writing skills, this class also helped me work on my critical thinking. From various readings of sports literature, I was able to take a deeper look at seemingly mundane things like the human body, what it is to watch a sport, and what the organization of sports in general might say about an individual or group of people.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class was extremely strong in that it allowed students to interact with text and define the relationship between sports and the world.
I don't think there was any way for it to be improved. It was a very interesting and comforting class.

Strengths - great feedback on essays and through writing process 
Weakness - readings were sometimes very long and dense.
Very fun, interesting readings. There were a lot of readings but they were interesting.
Strengths were the diverse materials we read and watched. The weakness was the level of engagement the class offered the students during the in person classes.

The readings are very well thought out and chosen, and Professor Creswell had an abundance of knowledge and great things to note avoit each work. I think it would serve the course well to have more student involvement on a day to day basis, like presentations and other things.
I believe the course was very strong in allowing everyone to engage and encouraging a student led discussion.

Professor Creswell is a clear strength of the course. He's so well-spoken and is so good at guiding our discussions. It seems like he always knows what to say and how to say it. He also does prep work based on our discussion posts, making the classes all the more engaging.

Being able to talk with actual authors and ask questions about their works was also incredibly exciting.

I wish we could engage with a work longer. It feels almost wasteful to read such a good book, discuss it for a class, then move on to the next one. But I don't think this is something that can/should be changed. I really enjoyed reading the wide array of works and you can't read such a wide array if you engage with a work longer.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The professor is engaging and the lectures are insightful.
Yes I would definitely recommend this class to anyone that is interested in the world of literature, sports literature and sports in general.
Yes, I would. Your success depends a lot on your own ability, participation, and work effort. If you work hard, you should be successful.
Yes - amazing professor, very relatable and good person.
Yes!
Yes. Great course if you are or are not interested in sports, because of what it teaches you beyond just the stereotypical view of sport.
Yes, it offers a very different approach to sports that is very interesting.
Yes. If you're interested in sports in general, that's probably enough of a reason to take the class. If you're interested in reading and discussing some really good sports literature, that's a plus.

Yes. The course offers an interesting variety of perspectives on different sports while stretching the idea of what counts as sport in the first place. Along with the content of the course, being in a seminar with classmates from different backgrounds and experiences with sports allows for engaging discussions, whether you approach things more from a literary perspective or from an athletic one-- not that they have to be completely separate things. Overall, it's a fun look at one of the biggest parts of human culture.
